title: Carbon market gives clearer rules on offsetting - FoodNavigator.com
summary: The article discusses the use of carbon offsetting by companies and the challenges faced by carbon markets in ensuring transparency and quality. Some companies are shifting away from relying on carbon offsets for achieving net zero emissions and are focusing on reducing their greenhouse gas emissions in their supply chains and operations.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article discusses innovations in carbon offsetting and strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, contributing to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: FALSE. The article focuses on carbon offsetting strategies and emissions reduction efforts rather than new product or process innovations.
green_product: FALSE. The article does not specifically mention the design, manufacture, or use of goods or services that significantly reduce environmental impact throughout their life cycle.
green_process: TRUE. The article discusses the implementation of green processes such as carbon offsetting and emissions reduction strategies in manufacturing and operational activities to minimize environmental impacts.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 541715 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences; 562998 - All Other Miscellaneous Waste Management Services; 926130 - Environmental Protection Organizations; 551112 - Offices of Other Holding Companies
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not mention any false or misleading environmental claims made by companies regarding their products or practices.

title: Two Direct-Air Carbon Removal Projects Set for $1.1B DOE Push - Engineering News-Record
summary: The U.S. Energy Dept. plans to fund two large direct-air carbon removal projects on the Gulf Coast, aiming to develop a domestic industry for carbon emissions reduction. Occidental Petroleum Corp. and Battelle are set to receive funding for their carbon capture and storage projects in Texas and Louisiana, respectively. The projects are part of a larger effort to scale up technology for removing CO2 from the atmosphere to support net-zero emissions goals by 2050.
green_innovation: TRUE - The article describes direct-air carbon removal projects that contribute to environmental sustainability goals by reducing carbon emissions and supporting net-zero emissions targets through innovative technology and processes.
business_innovation: TRUE - The article discusses new projects focused on developing and implementing carbon capture and storage technology, which differ significantly from existing processes in the energy sector, demonstrating a form of business innovation.
green_product: FALSE - The article focuses on carbon capture and storage projects, which do not align with the comprehensive definition of a green product involving the design, manufacture, and use of goods or services to minimize environmental impacts throughout their lifecycle.
green_process: TRUE - The article discusses the implementation of green processes such as carbon capture and storage techniques that aim to minimize environmental impacts, reduce waste, conserve resources, and limit the release of harmful substances into the environment.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 211112 - Natural Gas Liquid Extraction, 325120 - Industrial Gas Manufacturing, 562211 - Hazardous Waste Treatment and Disposal, 562910 - Remediation Services
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it focuses on real efforts by companies and organizations to develop carbon capture and storage projects to reduce carbon emissions and support sustainability goals.

title: Paving An Intentional Road To A Sustainable IT Future - The Next Platform
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of sustainable business practices, particularly regarding IT hardware recycling and refurbishing. It discusses the growing issue of e-waste and the need for companies to implement recycling strategies to adhere to environmental standards and gain consumer trust.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article focuses on sustainability practices, particularly in IT hardware recycling and refurbishing, aligning with green innovation principles of reducing waste and promoting environmental responsibility.
business_innovation: TRUE. The article highlights the introduction of new processes for recycling and refurbishing IT hardware, which differs significantly from traditional practices and aligns with the definition of business innovation.
green_product: TRUE. The article addresses the design and implementation of sustainable IT hardware solutions that reduce environmental impact through recycling, refurbishing, and proper disposal methods, meeting the criteria for a green product.
green_process: TRUE. The article discusses the implementation of green processes in the IT industry, specifically focusing on methods to reduce e-waste, conserve resources, and promote sustainable practices.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 334111 - Electronic Computer Manufacturing, 334119 - Other Computer Peripheral Equipment Manufacturing, 423930 - Recyclable Material Merchant Wholesalers, 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities
greenwashing: FALSE. The article does not exhibit greenwashing as it genuinely discusses the importance of sustainable business practices and addresses environmental issues related to e-waste management.
